thread.title: Railway Electrification Work To Restart

title: Railway Electrification Work To Restart
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 30, 2015, 21:52 BST - UK Markets closed Railway Electrification Work To Restart By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 34 minutes ago View Photo 

The electrification of two rail lines, which will lead to quicker journey times for thousands of passengers, is to go ahead after being stopped earlier this year. 
Work on the TransPennine Express Railway between Manchester and York and the Midland Mainline from London to Sheffield was suspended in June. 
The move came after Transport Secretary Patrick McLoughlin raised concerns about spiralling costs and missed targets at Network Rail. 
But he has now announced that work will restart - meaning faster journey times and significantly more capacity between Manchester, Leeds and York. 
The upgrade is expected to provide capacity for six fast or semi-fast trains per hour, and will take up to 15 minutes off the current journey time - of 75 minutes - between Manchester and York. 
The project is expected to take seven years to complete. 
The improvement will mean that by 2022 the whole route from Liverpool to Newcastle (via Manchester, Leeds and York) will be fully electrified. 
Adam Marshall, executive director of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: "Businesses were furious when these vital rail upgrades were shelved - and they will be delighted to see that work is set to resume. 
"Network Rail must now demonstrate that it can deliver these upgrades quickly and within budget. 
"We cannot afford to see any more stop-start infrastructure projects, as every pause and delay hurts business confidence and ultimately, productivity." 
Sir Peter Hendy, the chairman of Network Rail, is also proposing to recommence the electrification of Midland Mainline including the line north of Bedford to Kettering and Corby by 2019, and the line North of Kettering to Leicester, Derby/Nottingham and Sheffield by 2023. 
Commenting on the announcement Sir Peter said: “The temporary pause in the programme has given us the space to develop a better plan for passengers. 
"People can expect more services and faster journeys. 
"We face some difficult challenges, and there is more work still to do, but the Secretary of State’s decision means we can now move forward with our plans to electrify TransPennine and Midland Mainline”.
